elements.content: Despite the rise of uranyl-organic rotaxane compounds along with the prosperity of uranyl-organic frameworks, uranyl-based polyrotaxane compounds with high nuclearity have been rarely reported. In this work, a novel twofold nested uranyl polyrotaxane compound (1, [ (UO2)3O­(OH)3(C4CA4@CB6)1.5]·[(UO2)­(OH) (H2O) (C4CA4@CB6)0.5)]) with two different moieties, hexameric networks and dimeric chains, has been synthesized from C4CN4@CB6 (L1) using C4N4@CB6 (L3) as the induction agent. It is worth noting that the hexameric uranyl SBUs found here represent the highest nuclearity of uranyl found by far in uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks. When starting from C4CN3@CB6, a positional isomer of C4CN4@CB6 (L2), compound 2 ([(UO2)­(H2O)­(NO3)­(C4CA3@CB6)]·[(C4CA3@CB6)]) was obtained, which contains a one-dimensional polyrotaxane chain linked by another set of noncoordinated C4CA3@CB6 motifs through hydrogen bonding. Further characterization of compound 1 by fluorescence, IR, and Raman spectra was performed to analyze the features of the hexameric uranyl unit as well as dimeric unit. Meanwhile, the mechanism for the formation of 1 and 2 has been proposed by a comprehensive comparison with previously reported trimeric uranyl polyrotaxane networks, suggesting the vital role of self-template in the formation of uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks, especially for hexameric uranyl unit in 1.

elements.content: Metal–organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) consisting of metal centers connected by organic supramolecular linkers, using rotaxane motifs as mechanically interlocked molecules (MIMs), have attracted considerable attention of specialists in the field of material and chemistry. MORFs combine the porous characteristic of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with the dynamic property of MIMs; these emerging materials have shown fascinating potential in host–guest recognition, molecular machines, and luminescence. Similar to conventional methods to construct MOFs, multifarious MORFs structures can be successfully prepared by varying metal coordination environments or organic ligands. Up to now, a large amount of MORFs with one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), or even three-dimensional (3D) structures have been synthesized through coordination assembly of various pseudorotaxane/rotaxane precursor compounds with different metal centers. However, in comparison with traditional small-molecule linkers in MOFs, the inherent noncovalent feature of MIMs increases the difficulty to synthesize MORFs, especially those with sophisticated structures and potential applications as required.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic rotaxane frameworks (MORFs) consisting of metal centers connected by organic supramolecular linkers, using rotaxane motifs as mechanically interlocked molecules (MIMs), have attracted considerable attention of specialists in the field of material and chemistry. MORFs combine the porous characteristic of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with the dynamic property of MIMs; these emerging materials have shown fascinating potential in host-guest recognition, molecular machines, and luminescence. Similar to conventional methods to construct MOFs, multifarious MORFs structures can be successfully prepared by varying metal coordination environments or organic ligands. Up to now, a large amount of MORFs with one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), or even three-dimensional (3D) structures have been synthesized through coordination assembly of various pseudorotaxane/rotaxane precursor compounds with different metal centers. However, in comparison with traditional small-molecule linkers in MOFs, the inherent noncovalent feature of MIMs increases the difficulty to synthesize MORFs, especially those with sophisticated structures and potential applications as required.

elements.content: As one of the most representative actinide elements, uranium has been studied extensively due to its 5f orbital feature, as well as its significance in the nuclear fuel cycle. Uranyl, the stable state of uranium in aqueous systems, would hydrolyze in elevated pH, resulting in various secondary building units (SBUs) as demonstrated by many uranyl organic frameworks (UOFs). In addition, large-pore UOFs and similar actinide-based MOFs have been applied to the fields such as separation of environmental pollutants and radiation detection. As the metal node, uranyl has exhibited stronger architectural competence and abundant coordination environments. Due to the significance of uranium element, our group have been recently devoted to combining uranyl with cucurbituril-based supramolecular pseudorotaxane/rotaxane linkers and obtained a series of fascinating uranyl-based MORF structures with persistent effort.

elements.content: So far, among the plenty of uranyl SBUs, mono-, bi-, tri-, and tetra-nuclear uranyl motifs are commonly encountered in UOFs, while discrete uranyl motifs with higher nuclearity are relatively few. In the present work, by a hydrothermal reaction between a cyano-functionalized pseudorotaxane ligand (C4CN4@CB6, L1; see a), and uranyl in the presence of a second pseudorotaxane (C4N4@CB6, L3; see a), we successfully synthesized a novel twofold nested uranyl supra-polyrotaxane compound (1), which is assembled through 2D hexameric-uranyl-mediated polyrotaxane networks and 1D polyrotaxane chains with dimeric uranyl nodes (b). Actually, to the best of our knowledge, it is the first case of actinide polyrotaxane based on hexameric uranyl SBU, which represents by far the highest nuclearity of uranyl found in uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks. Interestingly, after altering the coordinated site of supramolecular ligand, i.e., using C4CN3@CB6 (a) instead of L1, another UORF compound (namely, 2) with only monomeric uranyl node was obtained under similar conditions. The detailed characterization of superpolyrotaxane compound 1 with both hexameric and dimeric uranyl nodes by infrared spectra (FTIR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and fluorescence has been conducted, and the corresponding analyses on the formation mechanism have also been demonstrated.

elements.content: Caution! Although uranyl nitrate UO2(NO3)2·6H2O used in the experiment was laboratory standard, suitable methods and effective precautions for handling radioactive substances should be taken. All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Cucurbit[6]­uril (CB6) was synthesized according to a published procedure. L1, L2, and L3 were synthesized by threading the cucurbit[6]­uril (CB[6]) to the relevant guest molecules, N,N′-bis­(4-cyanobenzyl)-1,4-diammoniobutane dinitrate (C4CN4), N,N′-bis­(3-cyanobenzyl)-1,4-diammoniobutane dinitrate (C4CN3), and N,N′-bis­(pyridin-4-ylmethyl)­butane-1,4-diaminium dinitrate (C4N4) (more details are shown in Supporting Information). Uranyl stock solution (0.5 M) was prepared prior to hydrothermal reaction by dissolving UO2(NO3)2·6H2O solid into deionized water.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Method

Caution! Although uranyl nitrate UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O used in the experiment was laboratory standard, suitable methods and effective precautions for handling radioactive substances should be taken. All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Cucurbit[6]uril (CB6) was synthesized according to a published procedure. L1, L2, and L3 were synthesized by threading the cucurbit[6]uril (CB[6]) to the relevant guest molecules, N,N'-bis(4-cyanobenzyl)-1,4-diammoniobutane dinitrate (C4CN4), N,N'-bis(3-cyanobenzyl)-1,4-diammoniobutane dinitrate (C4CN3), and N,N'-bis(pyridin-4-ylmethyl)butane-1,4-diaminium dinitrate (C4N4) (more details are shown in Supporting Information). Uranyl stock solution (0.5 M) was prepared prior to hydrothermal reaction by dissolving UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O solid into deionized water.

elements.content: 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker AVANCE III (500 MHz, Bruker, Switzerland) with deuterium oxide as a solvent. ESI-MS spectra were obtained with a Bruker AmaZon SLion-trap mass spectrometer (Bruker, USA). The FTIR spectra were recorded on KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on at Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer. Raman spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher Scientific DXRxi Micro Raman imaging spectrometer excited at 780 nm.

elements.content: 1([(UO2)3O­(OH)3(C4CA4@CB6)1.5]]·[(UO2)­(OH)­(H2O)­(C4CA4@CB6)0.5]): Compound 1 was synthesized by handling 0.5 M aqueous solution of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (80 μL, 0.04 mmol) with L1 (40 mg, 0.028 mmol) and L3 (40 mg, 0.024 mmol) in water (2 mL) in a stainless steel bomb, followed by adjusting the initial pH to 3.24 by adding NaOH. The bomb was sealed and heated at 180 °C for 72 h, and compound 1 as light yellow block crystals was obtained after the bomb was cooled to room temperature. Yield: 64.1 mg 41% based on uranium.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction of 1 was performed on Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray CMOS diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å) at room temperature, and X-ray diffraction of 2 was performed on the same diffractometer with a Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å). Using Olex2, all the crystal structures of 1 and 2 were solved by means of direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Due to the relatively weak diffraction capability and poor diffraction data of 1, rigid body (RIGU) restraints were used to constrain the sigma for all non-hydrogen atoms, and the use of a DFIX (C–C, O–C, N–C) restraint was necessary to create a chemically sensible model. For both 1 and 2, ISOR were used to constrain the displacement parameters and even out the electron density associated with disordered oxygen atoms. PLATON/SQUEEZE was used for 1 and 2 to afford neo-site diffraction intensities of solvent water molecules. The crystal data of two compounds are given in . Crystallographic data for the structures in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC-1587697 (1) and CCDC-1587698 (2).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Determination

X-ray diffraction of 1 was performed on Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray CMOS diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å) at room temperature, and X-ray diffraction of 2 was performed on the same diffractometer with a Mo Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.71073 Å). Using Olex2, all the crystal structures of 1 and 2 were solved by means of direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined with full-matrix least-squares on SHELXL-2014. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Due to the relatively weak diffraction capability and poor diffraction data of 1, rigid body (RIGU) restraints were used to constrain the sigma for all non-hydrogen atoms, and the use of a DFIX (C-C, O-C, N-C) restraint was necessary to create a chemically sensible model. For both 1 and 2, ISOR were used to constrain the displacement parameters and even out the electron density associated with disordered oxygen atoms. PLATON/SQUEEZE was used for 1 and 2 to afford neo-site diffraction intensities of solvent water molecules. The crystal data of two compounds are given in . Crystallographic data for the structures in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC-1587697 (1) and CCDC-1587698 (2).

The single crystal X-ray diffraction crystallography analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group, P1̅. Two crystallographically independent and distinct polymeric motifs, one-dimensional (1D) dimeric uranyl chain and two-dimensional (2D) layer based on uranyl hexamer, are found in 1. Each asymmetric uranyl unit in 1 contains four crystallographically unique metal ions with apical UO distances in the range of 1.773(17)–1.87(3) Å (). Specifically, the pentagonal bipyramidal polyhedron of U2 shares two edges with another two adjacent uranyl center (U1 and U2) to form a trimeric uranyl SBU, which is chelated by three supramolecular carboxyl linkers C4CA4@CB6, which is originated from in situ hydrolysis of cyano-bearing ligand L1 as well as a μ3-oxygen donor atoms O9 and two μ2-hydroxo atoms (O10 and O11). Sequentially, the trimeric uranyl motif shares one edge with the other to form a symmetric 6-connected hexameric-uranyl unit, and finally an independent 2D network is formed. The hexameric uranyl SBUs found here represents the highest nuclearity of uranyl found by far in uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks. Furthermore, the other submoiety obtained is the dimeric uranyl motif as shown in d. One μ2-carboxylate oxygen atom (U4–O21 2.46(3) Å, U4–O22 2.54(2) Å) and one terminal −OH (U4–O20 2.422(19) Å) coordinate to uranyl center, resulting in a uranyl dimer with two neighboring uranyl centers sharing equatorial edge to construct dimeric uranyl unit (Figure S3). A 1D polymeric chain is formed through the dimeric uranyl nodes connected by pseudorotaxane linkers. Ultimately, the 1D chains link all the 2D hexameric uranyl polyrotaxane networks apparently by a threading pattern to construct a unique twofold nested polyrotaxane framework with high-nuclear uranyl units ( and Figure S4), though the actual in situ assembly process under hydrothermal conditions is rather complex.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Description

The single crystal X-ray diffraction crystallography analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group, P1̅. Two crystallographically independent and distinct polymeric motifs, one-dimensional (1D) dimeric uranyl chain and two-dimensional (2D) layer based on uranyl hexamer, are found in 1. Each asymmetric uranyl unit in 1 contains four crystallographically unique metal ions with apical UO distances in the range of 1.773(17)-1.87(3) Å (). Specifically, the pentagonal bipyramidal polyhedron of U2 shares two edges with another two adjacent uranyl center (U1 and U2) to form a trimeric uranyl SBU, which is chelated by three supramolecular carboxyl linkers C4CA4@CB6, which is originated from in situ hydrolysis of cyano-bearing ligand L1 as well as a μ3-oxygen donor atoms O9 and two μ2-hydroxo atoms (O10 and O11). Sequentially, the trimeric uranyl motif shares one edge with the other to form a symmetric 6-connected hexameric-uranyl unit, and finally an independent 2D network is formed. The hexameric uranyl SBUs found here represents the highest nuclearity of uranyl found by far in uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks. Furthermore, the other submoiety obtained is the dimeric uranyl motif as shown in d. One μ2-carboxylate oxygen atom (U4-O21 2.46(3) Å, U4-O22 2.54(2) Å) and one terminal -OH (U4-O20 2.422(19) Å) coordinate to uranyl center, resulting in a uranyl dimer with two neighboring uranyl centers sharing equatorial edge to construct dimeric uranyl unit (Figure S3). A 1D polymeric chain is formed through the dimeric uranyl nodes connected by pseudorotaxane linkers. Ultimately, the 1D chains link all the 2D hexameric uranyl polyrotaxane networks apparently by a threading pattern to construct a unique twofold nested polyrotaxane framework with high-nuclear uranyl units ( and Figure S4), though the actual in situ assembly process under hydrothermal conditions is rather complex.

elements.content: When C4CN3@CB6, the positional isomer of C4CN4@CB6 (L1), was used as the precursor, another uranyl polyrotaxane compound 2 was captured. Unlike 1, compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and its asymmetric unit contains a unique monomeric uranyl motif and a η2-mode nitrate, one η1-mode carboxylate of C4CA3@CB6 formed in situ hydrolysis of C4CN3@CB6, as well as an uncoordinated ligand C4CA3@CB6 (a and Figure S5). This coordination method results in the three-connected uranyl SBUs and further extends to construct a one-dimensional zigzag polyrotaxane chain with monomeric uranyl as shown in c. Subsequent analysis suggests that nitrate ion in uranyl equatorial plane interacts with adjacent macrocycle CB[6] from the dissociative C4CA3@CB6 motif through hydrogen bonds (CH···O). Actually, hydrogen bonds act as the bridges to connect different 1D chains through the aid of dissociative C4CA3@CB6, largely contributing to the crystal packing and structural stabilization of 2 (d). The result of IR spectrum also reveals that nitrate ions are involved in 2 (Figure S7). Generally, as to the coordination of uranyl ions, the carboxylate groups have three combinational models, monodentate, bidentate, and bidentate bridging model. However, only the monodentate carboxylate group is observed in 2. A possible pathway is that in which η2-mode nitrate has been incorporated in uranyl equatorial plane so that coordination environment becomes crowded, which resulted from the abundant nitrate ions existing in systematic solution, or hydrogen bonds between nitrate and dissociative C4CA3@CB6 would reinforce the stability of nitrate in the uranyl equatorial plane. Two carboxylate groups have been incorporated into each uranyl motif and further extend to the zigzag one-dimensional structure. In compound 2, C4CA3@CB6, originating from in situ hydrolysis of C4CN3@CB6, has connected with uranyl chains nearby through the H-bonds (Figure S6).

However, only the monodentate carboxylate group is observed in 2. A possible pathway is that in which η2-mode nitrate has been incorporated in uranyl equatorial plane so that coordination environment becomes crowded, which resulted from the abundant nitrate ions existing in systematic solution, or hydrogen bonds between nitrate and dissociative C4CA3@CB6 would reinforce the stability of nitrate in the uranyl equatorial plane. Two carboxylate groups have been incorporated into each uranyl motif and further extend to the zigzag one-dimensional structure. In compound 2, C4CA3@CB6, originating from in situ hydrolysis of C4CN3@CB6, has connected with uranyl chains nearby through the H-bonds (Figure S6).

elements.content: For the MORFs utilizing cucurbituril-based pseudorotaxane/rotaxane linkers, only a handful of MORFs of this type have been reported. Besides porosity or dynamics for rotaxane-based MOFs, high-order assembly between different well-organized metal–organic rotaxane submoieties and the resulting complicated topology should also be taken into account, as another interesting issue concerning the supramolecular behavior of MORFs is high-order assembly between different well-organized metal–organic rotaxane submoieties just like the assembly of supercoil structure of DNA in biological systems. Whang et al. and Liang et al. have respectively reported different structural patterns with polycatenating through either inclined interweaving or parallel interpenetration. In fact, we described another polythreading model of uranyl-containing MORFs, which was based on another assembly mode, that is polythreading. The high-order assembly shown in the above cases verifies the feasibility employing cucurbituril-bearing supramolecular ligands to conduct the high-order assembly of MORFs. Further exploration on new MORFs with high-order assembly will help us to study and understand the supramolecular behavior and weak interactions of pseudorotaxane or rotaxane submoieties during the process of assembly.

Formation Mechanism of Uranyl Hexamer

For the MORFs utilizing cucurbituril-based pseudorotaxane/rotaxane linkers, only a handful of MORFs of this type have been reported. Besides porosity or dynamics for rotaxane-based MOFs, high-order assembly between different well-organized metal-organic rotaxane submoieties and the resulting complicated topology should also be taken into account, as another interesting issue concerning the supramolecular behavior of MORFs is high-order assembly between different well-organized metal-organic rotaxane submoieties just like the assembly of supercoil structure of DNA in biological systems. Whang et al. and Liang et al. have respectively reported different structural patterns with polycatenating through either inclined interweaving or parallel interpenetration. In fact, we described another polythreading model of uranyl-containing MORFs, which was based on another assembly mode, that is polythreading. The high-order assembly shown in the above cases verifies the feasibility employing cucurbituril-bearing supramolecular ligands to conduct the high-order assembly of MORFs. Further exploration on new MORFs with high-order assembly will help us to study and understand the supramolecular behavior and weak interactions of pseudorotaxane or rotaxane submoieties during the process of assembly.

elements.content: Compound 1 belongs to a polythreading model of uranyl-containing MORFs. Detailed analysis on crystal packing of 1 shows that each 1D uranyl chain goes through the triangle cavity of the 2D hexameric network with an incline angle of 121.1(2)°. The interlayer distance of 2D networks in 1 is 8.276 Å, while the distance between adjacent chains is 10.812 Å (). A similar assembly pattern is found in the previously reported superpolyrotaxane compound with the same pseudorotaxane linker (namely compound Super-U3-polyrotaxane). Interestingly, compounds 1 and Super-U3-polyrotaxane have analogous cell parameters, also suggesting their similarity in structure (). On the other hand, the main difference between 1 and Super-U3-polyrotaxane is uranyl nodes.

elements.content: As demonstrated above, 1 exhibits hexameric uranyl units and hydroxyl-bridging uranyl units in its 2D networks and 1D chains, which is slightly different from the trimeric uranyl motifs of the 2D network and the sulfate-bridging dimeric uranyl of the 1D chain in Super-U3-polyrotaxane. It is interesting to find that replacement of trimeric uranyl motifs by hexameric uranyl units or sulfate-bridging dimeric uranyl motifs by hydroxyl-bridging units from Super-U3-polyrotaxane to 1 does not alter the total configuration of 2D network or 1D chain, while it decreases the interlayer distance of the final polythreading framework from 13.94 Å in Super-U3-polyrotaxane to 8.27 Å in 1. Considering the vital role of 1D polyrotaxane chains in organizing the polythreading process for 1, the decrease of the interlayer distance of 2D networks might originate from the size of the subcomponent of 1D polyrotaxane chain inserted in the interlayer space of adjacent 2D networks. Actually, the distance between both ends of uranyl centers in adjacent uranyl SBUs have shortened from 34.955 to 31.637 Å when uranyl centers of 1D chains connect directly with each other by two bridging oxygen atoms rather than sulfate ions to construct dimeric uranyl SBUs (). Apparently, the size change tendency of the subcomponent of the 1D polyrotaxane chain is fully consistent with the decrease of interlayer distance of 2D networks, and this could provide a reasonable explanation for differing interlayer distances of 2D networks observed in 1 and Super-U3-polyrotaxane.

elements.content: Compound 1 affords the hexameric uranyl node at initial pH of 3.24. According to the uranyl hydrolysis equation: mUO2 2+ + nH2O ↔ [(UO2) m (OH) n ]2m‑n + nH+, in general, varied uranyl oligomers are observed at relatively high pH. Trimeric uranyl units in Super-U3-polyrotaxane are obtained at initial pH of 1.40. Uranyl hexamer can be seen as the product of uranyl trimer continuous hydrolysis. Moreover, if uranyl hexamer in 1 is taken as a simple integration of two opposite trimers in Super-U3-polyrotaxane, and this integration allows 2D polyrotaxane networks to have better coplanarity (). The 2D networks will become more smooth and orderly, and seem to be more suitable for crystal packing with shorter interlayer distances. Then, from this aspect, the shortened 1D chains of compound 1 could satisfy the requirement of hexameric uranyl-based 2D networks for shorter interlayer distances and be able to facilitate their high-order assembly.

elements.content: Another important question is the driving force promoting 2D networks aligning along the shortened 1D polyrotaxane chains. Detailed structural analysis shows that the CB6 molecules of the 1D chain, which locate at the interlayer space between two adjacent 2D networks, play a vital role in stabilizing the complex threaded structure by providing abundant CH···O­(axial) hydrogen bond interactions. Meanwhile, the dimeric uranyl SBUs also interact with adjacent CB6 molecules of 2D networks through multiple hydrogen bonds. It means that, in order to construct the wide-spreading H-bonds between CB6 (on 1D chains and 2D networks) and uranyl motifs (from hexameric or dimeric units) for the improved stability of polythreading framework structure ( and detail H-bond distance are placed in Table S1), the 2D polyrotaxane networks adapted themselves to the shorter sulfate-free chains by narrowing the interlayer distance. In other words, the 1D chains act as template agents, which provide H-bonding sites by CB6 macrocycles and uranyl SBUs to promote not only the formation of 2D networks and final polythreading frameworks, but also the reasonability of uranyl hexameric node.

elements.content: In order to figure out the role of auxiliary pseudorotaxane ligands, a comparison between 1 and 2 and other previously reported uranyl-organic rotaxane compounds with C4CN4@CB6 or C4CN3@CB6 was conducted (). For instance, originating from the same C4CN4@CB6 precursor like 1, a uranyl polyrotaxane with 2D network, namely, U2-polyrotaxane, was successfully achieved if no auxiliary ligands were utilized, while an equivalent amount of sulfate ion introduced into the system would produce a 2D+1D → 3D polythreaded uranyl polyrotaxane compound (Super-U3-polyrotaxane). Similar structural diversity of uranyl-organic rotaxane compounds has been observed for the series based on C4CN3@CB6, an isomer of C4CN4@CB6. When started from a simple uranyl source, the C4CN3@CB6 ligand offers a uranyl polyrotaxane in 1D dragon-like topology (IHEP-URCP-1). In addition, reducing the volume of the solution is conducive to the formation of uranyl oligomers, i.e., the 3D tetrameric uranyl polyrotaxane compound (IHEP-URCP-2) since a high concentrated hydrothermal system is provided. Interestingly, the method of reducing volume can only work without other competing ligands, as demonstrated by another sulfate-added 1D uranyl polyrotaxane compound (IHEP-URCP-3), which was constructed by intruding sulfate ions into uranyl-C4CA3@CB6 mixture.
elements.clean_text:
Templated Syntheses of 1 and 2: Exterior Templates and Interior Templates

In order to figure out the role of auxiliary pseudorotaxane ligands, a comparison between 1 and 2 and other previously reported uranyl-organic rotaxane compounds with C4CN4@CB6 or C4CN3@CB6 was conducted (). For instance, originating from the same C4CN4@CB6 precursor like 1, a uranyl polyrotaxane with 2D network, namely, U2-polyrotaxane, was successfully achieved if no auxiliary ligands were utilized, while an equivalent amount of sulfate ion introduced into the system would produce a 2D+1D → 3D polythreaded uranyl polyrotaxane compound (Super-U3-polyrotaxane). Similar structural diversity of uranyl-organic rotaxane compounds has been observed for the series based on C4CN3@CB6, an isomer of C4CN4@CB6. When started from a simple uranyl source, the C4CN3@CB6 ligand offers a uranyl polyrotaxane in 1D dragon-like topology (IHEP-URCP-1). In addition, reducing the volume of the solution is conducive to the formation of uranyl oligomers, i.e., the 3D tetrameric uranyl polyrotaxane compound (IHEP-URCP-2) since a high concentrated hydrothermal system is provided. Interestingly, the method of reducing volume can only work without other competing ligands, as demonstrated by another sulfate-added 1D uranyl polyrotaxane compound (IHEP-URCP-3), which was constructed by intruding sulfate ions into uranyl-C4CA3@CB6 mixture.

elements.content: As demonstrated above, the involvement of small completing anion as auxiliary ligand could effectively tune the construction of uranyl polyrotaxane, and induce the structural variation of uranyl polyrotaxane compounds. In the present work, the supramolecular ligand, C4N4@CB6, was first utilized in the hydrothermal systems of uranyl-pseudorotaxane. Unlike a small completing anion, C4N4@CB6 in our system influences the formation of uranyl polyrotaxane just through acting as an induction agent to promote the formation of 1 or 2 under hydrothermal conditions rather than participating in the coordination of the uranyl center. We can call it an induction agent here. On the other hand, it is found that the construction of these two uranyl polyrotaxane compounds, 1 and 2, is indeed related to the self-templated agent involved in their crystal structures. Correspondingly, we can name them “actual” template agents. Specifically, the 1D dimeric uranyl chains serve as the self-templating agent during the formation of the hexameric network in 1, in which the widespread hydrogen bonds between these two supramolecular motifs induce the formation of final compounds (). Similarly, compound 2 can also be seen as an interesting case of uranyl-organic complex with a self-template, where the noncoordinated C4CA3@CB6 in compound 2 providing hydrogen bonds and stabilizing the nitrate in uranyl equatorial plane does play a vital role. Therefore, both compounds 1 and 2 can be taken as two exquisite examples, which are synthesized by the induction of exterior template agents from second pseudorotaxane ligands, and meanwhile contain interior templates for the final crystal packing by the self-templated assembly.

Infrared Spectroscopy (IR), Raman Spectroscopy, and Fluorescence Spectroscopy

Compound 1, which can be obtained in sufficient amount of sample with good purity (Figure S7) was characterized by fluorescence spectroscopy, infrared spectroscopy (IR), and Raman spectroscopy, while compound 2 only received IR analysis due to its low yield.

elements.content: Fluorescence emission spectrum of 1 is shown in . It reveals that the broad emission band around the peak at 525 nm is consistent with that of the trimeric uranyl rotaxane coordination polymers in our previous work, as well as the hexameric uranylpyridinedicarboxylate compound reported by Chen et al. Moreover, for the IR spectra, both 1 and 2 exhibit characteristic peak of UO2 2+ around 920 cm–1 (Figure S8).

In this work, a novel twofold nested uranyl polyrotaxane compound with two different moieties, hexameric networks and dimeric chains, has been synthesized in the presence of a second pseudorotaxane. This synthesis process is ligand-dependent as demonstrated by the final product only with a one-dimensional polyrotaxane chain linked by another set of noncoordinated motifs through cross-linked hydrogen bonds when starting from an isomer of precursor. A comprehensive comparison with previously reported trimeric uranyl polyrotaxane networks suggests the vital role of self-template in the formation of uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks, especially for hexameric uranyl unit in 1. The results of this work indicate that template-driven assembly has great significance in the formation of a complicated uranyl coordination polymer with high-order assembly structure, and could been applied to the preparation of other uranyl-organic coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, a novel twofold nested uranyl polyrotaxane compound with two different moieties, hexameric networks and dimeric chains, has been synthesized in the presence of a second pseudorotaxane. This synthesis process is ligand-dependent as demonstrated by the final product only with a one-dimensional polyrotaxane chain linked by another set of noncoordinated motifs through cross-linked hydrogen bonds when starting from an isomer of precursor. A comprehensive comparison with previously reported trimeric uranyl polyrotaxane networks suggests the vital role of self-template in the formation of uranyl-organic rotaxane frameworks, especially for hexameric uranyl unit in 1. The results of this work indicate that template-driven assembly has great significance in the formation of a complicated uranyl coordination polymer with high-order assembly structure, and could been applied to the preparation of other uranyl-organic coordination polymers.

cln_elements.content:
1([(UO2)3O­(OH)3(C4CA4@CB6)1.5]]·[(UO2)­(OH)­(H2O)­(C4CA4@CB6)0.5]): Compound 1 was synthesized by handling 0.5 M aqueous solution of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (80 μL, 0.04 mmol) with L1 (40 mg, 0.028 mmol) and L3 (40 mg, 0.024 mmol) in water (2 mL) in a stainless steel bomb, followed by adjusting the initial pH to 3.24 by adding NaOH. The bomb was sealed and heated at 180 °C for 72 h, and compound 1 as light yellow block crystals was obtained after the bomb was cooled to room temperature. Yield: 64.1 mg 41% based on uranium.

2 ([(UO2)­(H2O)­(NO3)­(C4CA3@CB6)]·[(C4CA3@CB6)]): Compound 2 was synthesized by handling 0.5 M aqueous solution of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (70 μL, 0.035 mmol) with L2 (50 mg, 0.029 mmol) in the presence of L3 (50 mg, 0.025 mmol) in water (2 mL) in a stainless steel bomb, followed by adjusting the initial pH to 1.47 by adding HNO3. The bomb was sealed and heated at 180 °C for 72 h, and compound 2 in light yellow block crystals was obtained in very low yield after the bomb was cooled to room temperature.

cln_elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit in the crystal structure of 1. (b) Asymmetric unit of 1 with cucurbituril macrocyclic molecules omitted for clarity. Two types of well-organized submoieties in 1: (c) one part is 2D uranyl hexameric plane, and (d) the other is 1D uranyl dimeric chain.

Two types of well-organized submoieties in 1: (c) one part is 2D uranyl hexameric plane, and (d) the other is 1D uranyl dimeric chain.

cln_elements.content: (a) Polythreading 3D superpolyrotaxane framework of 1 based on hexameric uranyl monolayer threaded on an array of 1D dimeric uranyl chains (blue sky = 1D polyrotaxane chain, red = 2D polyrotaxane networks, light blue = cucurbituril macrocyclic molecules). (b) Cucurbituril macrocyclic molecules were omitted for simplicity. (c,d) View along different directions, the repetitive unit of 2D networks can accord with two 1D uranyl polyrotaxane chains. (e) Polythreading 3D superpolyrotaxane framework of 1 based on different uranyl hexamer layers. (f) Polythreading 3D superpolyrotaxane framework of 1 viewed along different directions. (g,h) Polythreading 3D framework with cucurbituril macrocyclic molecules omitted.
